bioghist.p: Joseph Castaldo was an American composer and longtime president of the Philadelphia Musical Academy (later known as the Philadelphia College of the Performing Arts). He studied composition at New York University, the New School, and the Manhattan School of Music. He joined the Philadelphia Conservatory of Music in 1954, becoming the school's president in 1966, a position he held for 17 years. During his tenure the school changed its name to the Philadelphia College of Performing Arts and later merged with the Philadelphia College of Art. Castaldo also founded the Philadelphia Composers' Forum and was composer-in-residence at the Grand Teton Music Festival. Castaldo's works have been performed by Andre Watts, Susan Starr, the Philadelphia Orchestra, the Baltimore Symphony Orchestra, and several esteemed string quartets.

scopecontent.p: This collection consists of scores and papers of Joseph Castaldo. The bulk of the collection is made up of scores and parts of his works, including Ancient Liturgies, Landscapes, and Where Silence Reigns (and many more). Other materials include two scrapbooks that consist largely of newspaper clippings, programs, and announcements; files related to performances of particular works, including programs, announcements, reviews, and correspondence; manuscript drafts of Castaldo's Creative Studies in Music; audio cassette and reel-to-reel recordings of a number of Castaldo's works; diplomas and certificates; and obituaries of Castaldo and memorial programs. The collection also includes a small amount of incoming and outgoing correspondence between Castaldo and publishers, concert organizers, orchestra librarians, and other musicians. Some of this correspondence relates to Castaldo's tenure at the Philadelphia College of the Performing Arts.

accessrestrict.p: The collection is open for research.
